text:
Hi <@U0293KR1KD2>, I think the KPIs for upper funnel content should be to lead the reader to the _next level_ in the funnel, not all the way down to the sale. That's why it's called a funnel, most users will go through the stages in time. One of the biggest errors I see business leaders do is expect us to deliver sales or SQLs directly from the top of the funnel.

For example, with a simple 3-level funnel:
• top-funnel content KPIs: traffic + clicking to read content that it's part of the next level
• mid-funnel content KPIs: clicking on product descriptions (=bottom of funnel content)
• bottom-funnel content KPIs: app installs, etc., whatever conversion means to your business
For this, you would need to categorize all your content per funnel stage and then aim for each piece to lead the reader to content belonging to the next stage in the funnel.

That's my view on this. What do you think?

text:
Thanks <@U024K88ECFN> and <@U02TYAMTVK8>! Ha, I realized as I wrote this question that it’s almost existential for content marketing. I totally agree, Monica, about thinking about moving people through the funnel with content, and I’m working on a mid-funnel content hub this year, with that in mind. I LOVE that thinking. What happens, for me, is that inevitably, someone higher up than me (but not my boss) will come around asking things like: “how many new customer conversions does our blog content drive?” And it’s usually in a resourcing context, such as during 2022 planning, and I’m asking for more money for content production, and somebody wants to know about ROI.

Maybe it’s more about evangelizing our content strategy across the company. I did that when I started but I could do it again, certainly. It’s super-helpful, anyway, to return to the funnel model and to reiterate for myself and anyone asking that upper funnel content is not optimized for bottom-line conversions, nor should it be.

text: Hey <@U0293KR1KD2>! This is what I think about all day at Knotch - both for my job and because we as a company want to change what ROI really stands for content. It’s not “fair” for upper funnel content to be held to lower-funnel metrics. So for a blog we’d look at things like recirculation rates (did it lead to another article?), reader sentiment (something we use our own tool for) and defining important ‘next steps.’
